isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS

svcproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC ANALYIS PROCEDURES FOR OIL CONSUMPTION
svcproc.para: When analyzing a lube oil consumption problem proceed as follows:

step1.para: Visually inspect for external oil leaks and correct.
Check for air cleaner restriction, air induction system leaks and excessive crankcase pressure.

note.para: Change the oil filter element and inspect the turbocharger for damage if lube oil is drawn into the engine.

step1.para: If items 1 and 2 are NOT the cause, continue analysis.

step2.para: Change the oil (using the recommended API Specification and viscosity for the ambient temperature).
Determine initial oil consumption rate and trend at:
Record the amount of make up lube oil added during the test period.

item.para: Verify the engine is equipped with the proper dipstick. The wrong dipstick may result in erroneous reading.
Lube oil level must be "topped" [with engine hot, after a 15 min. shutdown period], at the beginning and at the end of each oil consumption test period.

step1.para: If oil consumption was excessive, determine the cause of the problem:

item.para: Abnormally heavy loads pulled by the vehicle. (Above the specified GVW.)
Improper operation (i.e. allowing the engine to lug in the incorrect gear range) resulting in oil consumption.
Faulty air compressor. (If compressor piston rings are worn, oil can be forced into the air system.)
Worn engine valve guides or valve stem seals. (Clean and inspect.)
Worn rings and/or bores due to normal wear or dirt passing the air filter element. (Perform crankcase pressure test.)
Defective injector "O" ring(s) allowing oil to mix with fuel. Refer to ICP leakage test in Hard Start/No Start diagnostics.
